channel.title: DOM & jQuery II on JavaScript
channel.description: Recent content in DOM & jQuery II on JavaScript

item.title: Objectives
item.description: Understand the benefits of $(this) or $(event.currentTarget) Explain how the type of function used (regular or array) dictates usage of $(this) or $(event.currentTarget) Use knowledge of DOM manipulation with jQuery to build small frontend applications

item.title: Warm Up: Iterators Practice
item.description: Warm Up: Iterators Practice Work in groups of 2-3 to solve problems using functions Only use either .map(), .find() or .filter() to solve the problems in the problem set Do not use .forEach() The problem set for this warm up is hosted on Github, see the url below: Warm Up: Iterators Practice Use the Assignment Submission Git Workflow (detailed here) to access and submit the assignment

item.title: $(this)
item.description: $(this) this one of the most misunderstood concepts in JavaScript this (native JavaScript) refers to the owner of a function $(this) (jquery) gives you reference to uses jQuery to select the current element We’ll cover the this (native JavaScript) in later in the course Example $(() => { $("#box").click(function() { // use $(this) with with regular function syntax // to reference the element that is being "acted on" $(this).

item.title: event.currentTarget
item.description: event.currentTarget JavaScript property (not specific to jQuery) that identifies the current target for the event It always refers to the element to which the event handler has been attached, as opposed Similar to $(this), with the added benefit that it works with arrow functions When using event.currentTarget in the context of jQuery, it should be wrapped in a jQuery object: $(event.currentTarget) Example $(() => { $("#box").
